title: Hyperdimensional Intelligent Sensing for Efficient Real-Time Audio Processing on Extreme Edge
author: Sanggeon Yun (University of California, Irvine), Ryozo Masukawa (University of California, Irvine), Hanning Chen (University of California, Irvine), SungHeon Jeong (University of California, Irvine), Wenjun Huang (University of California, Irvine), Arghavan Rezvani (University of California, Irvine), Minhyoung Na (Kookmin University), Yoshiki Yamaguchi (Shibaura Institute of Technology), Mohsen Imani (University of California, Irvine)
relevance_why: The paper presents advances in energy-efficient audio processing, which could be adapted to enhance audio signal processing tasks that Haohe Liu is exploring, particularly in the context of efficient audio generation and enhancement.
background: The paper addresses the task of efficient audio processing on edge devices, specifically focusing on detecting relevant audio events to reduce latency and energy consumption.
contribution: This paper introduces a near-sensor model utilizing HyperDimensional Computing (HDC) for real-time audio detection, achieving up to 82.1% energy savings with minimal quality loss.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional deep learning models for audio applications are often too resource-intensive for edge devices and lack efficient online learning capabilities.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines convolutional neural networks with hyperdimensional computing to create a lightweight model that retains flexibility for online learning and significantly enhances energy efficiency.

key_innovation: The integration of HyperDimensional Computing with minimal convolutional layers allows for rapid, adaptive audio inferencing with lower energy needs.
real_world_impact: The model could revolutionize audio sensing applications in real-time environments, such as gunshot detection, allowing for improved safety and efficiency in public spaces while minimizing resource consumption.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.HyperDimensional Computing (HDC): **HyperDimensional Computing (HDC)** is a computational framework inspired by the human brain's processing, utilizing high-dimensional vectors for efficient data encoding and classification.
